intro: Eschscholzia douglasii var. parvula, commonly known as the dwarf California poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Papaveraceae family and is characterized by its delicate, bright orange to red petals. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with narrow, lance-shaped leaves and a compact, bushy habit. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in coastal and inland valleys. Its flowers bloom from spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
